title: Companies buying Solana? Upexi CEO and CSO explain why

Chief Strategy Officer Brian Rudik.
Welcome to the show. How are you all
doing?
Doing well Tim. Thanks for having uh
myself and Brian today. Yeah, thank you
very much. Brilliant. Now before we get

blockchains

for a public company. You know, the

Only Salana. We Yeah. Yeah. We probably

So, I think I think just learning to

Gotcha. Okay. How do you think uh sort

cleanText:
Today we have Upexi CEO Alan Marshall and Chief Strategy Officer Brian Rudik.

Welcome to the show.
How are you all doing?

Doing well, Tim.
Thanks for having uh myself and Brian today.
Yeah, thank you very much.
Brilliant.
Now before we get started, quick note.
If you are hiring crypto, you should check out Campus out of all of your candidates.
It will help you pick out the real crypto natives.
Head to theblock.co/campus to get a three-month free trial.
Now, today's episode is about crypto treasury strategies.
This is something I've been noticing has been a growing trend recently, and I think some people are starting to get a little bit concerned if it's getting a bit out of hand.
Um, so I'm going to grill you guys a little bit about this, and maybe you can put me at ease.
Um, so just to begin with, what made you choose Solana for the Treasury play?

Hi, Brian.
Brian.
Yeah.
So for us it was a pretty easy decision.
Um I look at Bitcoin as the best monetary asset and Solana as the best high-performance blockchain.
Um there are obviously 20 or more um micro strategy imposters.
We didn't want to be the 21st.
Um we'd rather be the canonical Solana treasury company.
And then the second thing is Bitcoin is a $2 trillion dollar asset.
So it is literally the seventh largest in the world.
It is unlikely to 5x anytime soon versus Solana, which is literally 4% the market cap of Bitcoin.
Um it could 5x year end, and so for us it just made a lot of sense to be underpinned by the leading high-performance blockchain.
To get into a couple uh details around that.
So Solana, in my opinion, is like the first second-gen blockchain.
So it has a lot of big innovations over something like Ethereum, and I think you're seeing that emanate in best-in-class performance.
Uh and then lastly, that is attracting this large and growing ecosystem of users, developers, and DApps.
So you're seeing like Solana put up the best metrics out of any chain uh even at uh a smaller market cap than some others.
So uh yeah, for us it was pretty easy.
We see Solana as uh an endgame winner for high-performance blockchains and also as an asset for a public for a public company.
You know, the staking revenue adds another another kind of tier of of profitability for us.
So that was one of the other kind of like things that that really pushed us towards like Upexi.
After speaking with Brian about that is that that was what why was the final decision on that being that having adding that to our um repertoire of revenue possibilities and growth.
Yeah.
How how does the staking revenue work if it's locked Solana?
Do you still get the staking rewards and you can sell them or are they locked in accordance with the vesting schedule?
Uh the staking revenue is still paid uh well it's still earned u and it and it it unlocks uh whatever the linear schedule is, whether it's 20 months, 30 months, 36 months.
So every month it unlocks and then we move that from locked into into a liquid position monthly.
Yeah, just to double click on that.
So we have a lot of value accrual mechanisms that all compound and our ability to access lock at a discount is one of them.
Um, most individuals actually can't get that, but we can.
Uh, and then when we do buy lock sold at this 15 to 20% discount, those are built-in gains for shareholders.
If you put this discount on any sort of yield equivalent metric, um, we are roughly doubling the staking yield and we're doing it in this risk prudent fashion.
Um, lock actually does have a fairly liquid OTC market.
So, we could sell it if we want, but like we have pledged never to sell our soul.
Uh we're a buy and huddle only strategy.
So buying lock at this discount, given that we're not going to sell it, really aligns with our strategy and then provides for those gains for shareholders.

And in terms of like where you got it from, is this uh ultimately from the sort of pool of locker from the FTX estate that was sort of sold to a bunch of you know firms over like the last year?
That that's one of many sources of it.
Um they're there ultimately other sources of it, but so we so we buy from all from all sources.
And one thing that differentiates us, so we're backed by 15 leading crypto VCs, a lot of them own a lot of this uh and so we're working with them and different brokers uh to where like they could easily drum up and we we do feel that we have better access to lock soul than others might.

Okay, and where do you see Solana's adoption in the next sort of, you know, one to three years and how does that impact your long-term strategy?
I'm super excited for the next three years.
Um, in my mind, the biggest thing always holding crypto back in general were unclear rules and regulations in the US.
I think we could actually be on the precipice of the mother of all bull markets because hopefully, fingers crossed, we will get digital asset legislation in the US next year.
And the reason why this is so important is if this happens, institutions will have to jump in in a big way.
Um, it's a little antithetical to like crypto, but is actually these big institutions that have literally billions of customers, billions of dollars to throw at it, a lot of the top devs, and built-in trust.
And so if you can imagine something like Google Chrome adding a built-in crypto wallet and then Amazon accepting USDC payments, like we will just on board the masses.
And so I actually think like we could be on the precipice of this step change function in usage and adoption and Upexi and Solana will be big benefactors of that.

And is your Solana strategy more compelling since there isn't an ETF for it where there sort of obviously is for Bitcoin and Ethereum because it's sort of harder for especially traditional companies to get exposure?
I think that's both in both.
One is right now today, you know, it's a it's it's pure access to to owning Solana directly.
Also, because of the with the way treasury companies trade at NAV, like anticipating that future growth and that staking revenue, people can make a multiple on on their, you know, investment possibly, you know, historically on way on where these trade.
Um, but we welcome an ETF.
The more exposure for Solana and the more holders and the more you know it becomes more mainstream, it's just better for the underlying asset itself.
So we think we think having an ETF is going to be you know even more beneficial for us and for companies in the future.
I'll just double click with an example if it's okay.
So BlackRock filed in mid-2023 for a Bitcoin ETF.
Um Bitcoin was roughly at 25K and then by the time it went live in January of the next year, Bitcoin was in the 45 to 50K range and then you saw really strong flows and it pushed it up to 70K.
So you had Bitcoin more than double due to an ETF and you saw MicroStrategy perform exceptionally well over that time.
Um so I am actually looking at uh spot Solana ETF as really good for us uh and for Solana as a whole.
So, um, we're excited about this, uh, and looking at it squarely as a big positive catalyst.

And how long do you think until we see a SOL ETF?
Speculation.
We I mean, I think a lot of people thought,
uh, we may have just lost Alan.
I think you're back.
Yeah, I think I I I'm traveling today, so I'm in New York.
Saying that the uh network but um I lost our our train of thought there.
Sorry about that.
Um sometime this year I would hope, but I think that the staking revenue is actually causing a little issue is what I heard is that how them figuring out how to how to stake it is causing a little bit of an issue.
I've seen a lot of ETF experts saying, you know, we're in the 90% range for getting one this year.
Uh there was just some headlines out uh two days ago basically saying that it could happen this month.
So, we're hopeful that it will happen sooner rather than later, but just like Alan said, it's a bit TBD.

Okay.
And why did you decide to adopt a treasury strategy?
One of the, you know, changes, you know, we added, we added the treasury strategy to our business because as we watched over the years the the value MicroStrategy creates it.
We were trying to figure ways to to to bring Upexi into, you know, its next its next stage.
And when we were looking at raising capital and doing something, you know, creative, we were we were wa we decided on some sort of treasury strategy and looking at the the value that was created by MicroStrategy over the years and then us having to meet with GSR and then Brian and and we, you know, what we learned in that relationship was just the value of of how it was created.
And I can let Brian get into, you know, more how the value was created with MicroStrategies, but really that was what kind of led Upexi into entering the new strategy.
Yeah.
Um, what I'd say is there I mean digital asset treasury companies when done right can just create an enormous amount of value and might be the best way to invest in a digital asset for a lot of different investors.
And so I will back up and I will say that I spent most of my career on Wall Street.
I was managing a book of bank stocks always in a long short construct for Citadel, Millennium, and Balesnney.
And the reason why that's important is these are just banks.
And so like if you think about it, a bank will take a deposit, make a loan, they earn the spread between the yield on the loan and the cost of deposits.
We're the exact same way.
We raise funds from the capital markets.
We invest in Solana and then we earn the return between uh or the spread between the return on Solana and our cost of capital.
And so uh I think that plus the fact that knowing that when you issue equity above book value it is by definition accretive enabled me to really internalize where all this value creation emanates from.
And so we just basically employing that same model.
Um we're following what MicroStrategy has done and actually trying to improve on it.
So, like Allan mentioned, we are staking our soul and we're turning our treasury into this productive asset rather than letting it sit there idle.
We are buying locked soul uh at a discount for built-in gains for shareholders.
And then the whole capital markets flywheel where in my opinion most of this magic actually emanates from.
It's almost tantamount to capital markets arbitrage.
I can get into the math and explain this in much more detail, but when the market awards us a premium to the underlying value of our digital assets, we can actually monetize that for the benefit of shareholders.
And so, uh, yeah, it really is for all the value creation that we can do, which is what caused us to really push on this and and move into it in a big way.

Why should there be a premium on in these sorts of cases or or why is there?
In my mind, it really emanates for three reasons.
One is just the market wants access to crypto in the form of a familiar equity security.
Uh they essentially want to buy soul in their Schwab account.
You saw this with Grayscale's closed-end trust G Soul where before it filed to convert to an ETF it was rough it was routinely trading at a 500% plus premium.
Um I also think that this emanates from uh access to these different value accrual mechanisms that you otherwise wouldn't get.
Uh and for example this is like our ability to buy lock at a discount.
And then the last reason is just putting my bank investor hat on.
Going right back to that example of us earning the spread between the return on soul and our cost of capital.
Uh essentially we earn that spread not just this year but in future years as well.
And so when the market expects us or Solana to have strong future returns that spread is quite positive and they will present value that add it to the NAV and that's where that that premium emanates from.
Um yeah and then we can like I mentioned monetize that for shareholders.

Well in the case of like strategy you can already get exposure through you know through the bitcoin ETFs.
Why therefore is there sort of a premium if it's allowing access that you know the idea is that it allows access that you don't have otherwise in strategy's case you do have access to bitcoin.
So so why does the premium exist there?
This comes from a lot of the intelligent capital markets issuance.
You can actually get into this capital markets flywheel.
So let's start with the premise that folks are willing to ascribe this premium to MicroStrategy.
I'll use them as an example.
Let's just say they trade it two times.
Um then what MicroStrategy will do is it will go out and it will raise equity at two times.
And when you raise equity at two times book, you are essentially selling a dollar for two or it's tantamount to buying Bitcoin half off.
And so what that results in is your Bitcoin per share moving up and then if your Bitcoin per share moves up, your stock should move up accordingly and that helps you maintain that premium multiple and then the cycle will just continue.
So essentially if you buy into MicroStrategy uh at like a two times multiple you are buying half a Bitcoin, but if you expect them to continue to compound that Bitcoin per share you're actually will be better off over time.
And so that's basically the way that it works.
What I'd say is like MicroStrategy increased Bitcoin per share 74% last year.
And so as long as you continue to expect them to be able to do this intelligent capital issuance and increase Bitcoin per share, even though you're buying in at this premium to underlying book, you will soon be better off if that comes if they continue to do that.

Okay.
So people sort of buy in on the expectation that they sort of think a greater fall at some point is is going to come in later.
Um and it just sort of keeps going until essentially you run out of sort of new people coming in.
Not that not a greater fool really because a lot of this like the biggest thing that will determine MicroStrategy's success or our success is like the performance of the underlying token.
Uh, which is why it's super important to make sure if you do invest in a digital asset treasury company that you're doing one that is underpinned by a token that you think will not only be around in five years, but will continue to outperform and can be an endgame winner.
Um but I think a lot of this just emanates from these strong views on forward uh Solana returns or Bitcoin returns and then uh the companies being able to monetize that for shareholders and with and with Solana I think people are not only anticipating the growth of the the price of Solana they're also on Wall Street they're able to add in and you know forward look at that that yielding uh of the st


aking revenue.
So that's one of the other reasons, like, that was what we talked about earlier.
We think that's a differentiator for us than, than even from Bitcoin, even though Bitcoin, you know, is obviously the premium asset for digital, but we think that gives Solana treasury company a little bit of an advantage.
Okay.
And what would happen in this situation, uh, where, like, Solana, the price of Solana to drop 96% again, like it did a few years ago?
Like, what happens in that situation?
So, it depends on the company.
Yeah.
Go ahead, Brian.
It's a big speculation, but yeah.
So, one, what I would say is, um, I think, like, a lot of these black swan events, um, are now probably over with, um, for Solana.
So, obviously, like, FTX was very well tied into Solana.
I don't think, like, there is that vector anymore, obviously.
Um, and, like, I was mentioning, I actually think when looking at positive catalysts and putting things on a risk-reward basis, there's many more things that could go right than could go wrong.
Um, but what I'd say is, like, it's also really important for investors to actually look at each company's capital stack and the amount of leverage anyone is taking on.
So, for us, um, we are funded entirely by equity.
So, we raised a $100 million pipe, uh, and we were not taking on any leverage.
We have disclosed that we have this small line, uh, which we can pay back at any time, but basically, we want to do things in this risk-prudent fashion where you should take out a little bit of leverage if you are betting on an asset that will tend to move up over the medium term, but you have to make sure you don't take on too much leverage, uh, to where you can get in trouble and become a forced seller if the environment turns on you for unforeseen reasons.
And so, we are growing, uh, and we are maximizing shareholder value, but we are doing it in this risk-prudent fashion to make sure that we can weather all market environments.
Um, I think, like, it's obviously very tempting to take out as much leverage as possible, uh, to try to grow soul as much as possible or BTC as much as possible, but we're making sure we're doing this in this, like, risk-managed way, uh, to where, like, we'll be here no matter what.
So, can you clarify, like, the extent of the leverage you have then?
Um, we, we, we disclosed it on the filing what we have, but we can't give you any real-time lifetime access to that because it's not public information, but we, we're maintaining, we, we've said publicly, we're trying to maintain under 20% leverage, which would allow us to weather most storms.
That is where, just to give you a comparison, that is where, uh, MicroStrategy places their leverage limit.
So, they won't take out debt greater than 20% relative to their NAV, and we're the exact same way.
Okay.
So, what sort of, like, price drop could sort of be stomach?
Like, you know, is, like, 80, 90% fine, or, or is that, like, game over at that sort of level of leverage?
Well, that, I mean, that's, that's a big, big assumption that we wouldn't make any moves along that time, but, uh, I think with, with 80% with 20% leverage and 80% downturn, you know, and some people, you know, we want to talk about, you know, the all the downside with it, you know, obviously for us, if we have cash available in those times, those are just opportunities for us to add to, to, to treasury at that moment in time.
So, even though it sounds scary for downturns, downturns for companies who are prepared with both capital available and a good cap structure would use that to, like, like MicroStrategy has done over time.
We just use that to add to the treasury, you know, giving the shareholders a much bigger opportunity in the future.
Yeah, just to put it in perspective, and I'll speak in MicroStrategy terms, like, last I looked, they had 45 billion of unencumbered Bitcoin.
Uh, they do have convertible notes outstanding.
They have laded those with different maturities, and the different studies that I've seen is you would really need Bitcoin to fall 95% for, you know, five to seven years for there to be any credit risk and force selling.
Um, and so we're trying to, uh, position ourselves the same way to where, you know, I think if we were in that environment, we've all got bigger things to worry about.
But, uh, but yes, um, yeah, I mean, it is, there is always risk around that, but we view it as, um, hopefully minimized.
Okay.
Um, and do you think in terms of, like, the large amounts of locked soul that have been sold over, like, the last few years and sort of becoming available?
Do you think that is, is, is sort of depressing the price to some degree?
Of keeping it, um, around the sort of, I mean, a lot of it was sold around $130, $140.
Um, with that sort of continuous supply coming to the market, do you think that's might, uh, frustrate it for, for a couple of years, or, or is that nothing that investors need to worry about?
I think this probably goes to, you know, why Upexi, pivoting, a lot of companies are pivoting to tra, to treasury companies or to, to more access to, uh, crypto, right?
As, as this administration now seems to have taken a tailwind, like a headwind provided over the last couple years to a tailwind here in the next four years.
Hopefully, you know, that overall adoption of crypto would, would eat up all of that, you know, all of the excess or whatever people anticipate.
We don't think there's an excess, but depending on your point of view, just that tailwind should provide support for, for the top digital assets.
There's not actually a ton out there.
Um, many months ago, there was, I think you can almost look at the discounts as a proxy for how much supply of locked soul there is, and those discounts, obviously, in the crypto winter were 50% plus, now they're, like, mid-teens roughly.
Um, and so what I'd say is, even when we first launched, we were getting marketed, uh, just like lock at a discount quite often, it's much less so now.
Um, I'd say, like, we're not worried about our ability to access lock because we know and are close with all the major players, even if there are none out there being advertised as for sale, like, we can always ping all the major holders.
Um, and also, too, a lot of the blocks that we're seeing are larger blocks to where, you know, you have a very limited set of buyers.
There's not that many folks that can actually act on that.
You know, we are one of them.
And so, we think we'll still have good access, but I'm actually not, like, personally that worried about, like, a lot of lock soul being for sale depressing the price of Solana.
Okay.
What do you guys make of, uh, GameStop dropping 20%, uh, and Sharink dropping around 70%, um, after the sort of, you know, latest Treasury Reserve announcements?
I mean, I could comment on GameStop.
Means, uh, just a constant, constant change of business model and unlimited equity financings for a business losing ridiculous amounts of money.
But, um, so on ESBA, we think, you know, even, even with these dig digital strategy companies, people have to understand how the value takes time.
So, we don't want to comment on anyone else's trading, but we're not too worried about it.
We believe in a strategy.
So, you know, we, we, we certainly wish, you know, ESP the best, and we have confidence that that, that their multiple will find its way, just like ours were.
Ours will over time.
There's, I think I could mention this.
So, there's, like, a technical versus fundamental component happening here to where they raised a large pipe.
Uh, a lot of the folks in it, like, you can look at the S3 and see who it was.
Um, and then what I'd say is, like, uh, you know, I think over the short term, there could be some folks that are looking to take gains, but over the long term, like, there is a potential for them to garner a more peer-like multiple.
Um, in my stance, um, without getting too much into valuation, like, as you are a smaller company underpinned by an asset with all else equal, more growth potential, you should take this higher multiple.
So, I say that relative to, like, MicroStrategy, which last I looked was at 17.
A lot of smaller companies, uh, should have this embedded growth premium, and then when you move off BTC, there should be this additional growth premium for growth in the underlying asset as well.
So, um, yeah, maybe I'll leave it there, but I think, like, over the long term, the fundamentals should come back in and overwhelm where some short-term technical selling pressure could be, you know, pushing the stock down maybe temporarily.
Okay.
And do you have any concerns about the number of companies that are acquiring these leverage positions?
U, most of them are for Bitcoin.
Uh, I believe Anthony Pompiano is the latest person to set up a company to buy Bitcoin.
Like, it just, it's definitely a flywheel for sure, but, but do you sort of have any concerns that it, it's sort of building up a little bit too much?
I mean, we try to stay focused on our business and what we're doing.
Now, obviously, we get concerned if, if people or companies, you know, do things that are irresponsible or too much leverage that maybe affect the perspective of the industry, but alls we can do is, you know, manage our house accordingly, and like Brian and I and our team plan to really just operate in a, you know, very, very forward-facing and professional manner and stick to our leverage and and just operate our business.
But, you know, obviously, there's a concern when this over, but we can't, we can't be responsible or or or worry too much about that.
The other thing that I'd add is this exactly right.
Like, if you do things in a manner that is not befitting for a public company, you're imposing risks, but when done right, I actually think digital asset treasury companies are supremely positive for the token ecosystems that underly them.
Uh, and it's really for two reasons.
One is, um, we are effectively a one-way acquisition vehicle for soul, meaning that we have a buy and huddle strategy.
The endgame is for us not to push up price, but that could result because of it.
And while this is not what we're trying to do, like a rising price will be beneficial for Solana to attract users, developers, and DAPs.
Um, the second big thing is that we are raising visibility of Solana, particularly with traditional investors and institutions.
I can't tell you how many calls Allan and I have done with sellside analysts, and a lot of them are asking what's the difference between a smart contract blockchain and, like, Bitcoin, and, you know, what is Solana, and what differentiates Solana, and we're out there evangelizing Solana to Wall Street, and I think, like, this is just a huge, huge benefit, uh, that we can provide, uh, the entire ecosystem.
Sure.
And have you modeled out what could happen if strategies Bitcoin play unwinded, uh, very rapidly?
No.
No, we haven't.
Other than to say, like, I think the odds are quite low, and you're seeing that with, like, the convertible investors giving them a basically free funding in the form of 0% interest rate.
So, I think, like, they are also effectively saying they think there is almost no credit risk there.
Um, so, yeah, we haven't modeled it out exactly, but would just mention that at least I personally ascribe very low odds to that happening.
Okay.
We try not to model out all the doom in the world.
We try to keep a perspective of, of something that we, you know, we think the future's a little brighter than that.
For sure.
For sure.
Maybe I'm paranoid because I've been through so many sort of major systemic things in crypto from, you know, Luna, FTX, um, and, you know, and I, I've only been here and here not as long as Yeah.
But it, it's the same as it's the same as Wall Street, right?
We've been through all of the same things on Wall Street.
And the truth is, whether you go back to, you know, the housing crisis, the, you know, the, the crashes, I mean, anyone who's been steady and well, I mean, just look at Warren Buffett and the greatest investors, they, they just ride through that.
They maintain a really steady hand.
They don't get panicked out by those.
I think crypto has a lot of these, you know, things that are more severe because the investing public in it is probably a little bit younger and more apt to, you know, react a little, little, a little more, I guess, emotionally.
But we, we really, you know, think that whether it's a crypto winner or a good time, that if you're steady through it and we maintain a good process, that it should turn out, you know, in a, you know, the best possible scenario.
Yeah.
I'd point out that there are these inevitable crypto winners, but there are also these inevitable crypto boom periods.
And if you look at a company that does things right, like MicroStrategy, um, you're just kind of on pause during these crypto winners.
And so, as long as you don't get over your skis, and I think, like, the best metric for MicroStrategy is Bitcoin per share.
So, in 2022, 2023, they were just a bit on pause with the capital market strategy.
They still increased Bitcoin per share by mid-single digits.
And then last year, as you move into this inevitable boom period, they were able to increase Bitcoin per share 74%.
